_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Hess Corporation
Americas Production

United States Environmental Protection Agency - Risk Management Program

                                                                 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

                                         CERTIFICATION LETTER - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


The Tioga Gas Plant Complex High Pressure Inlet Receiver and Condensate Process is being submitted as a Level 3 for both flammables and toxics.  The other processes in the Tioga Gas Plant Complex are being resubmitted as a Level 1 for flammables.

FLAMMABLES
Based on the criteria in 40 CFR 68.10, the distance to the specified endpoint for the flammables worst-case accidental release scenario for the Tioga Gas Plant Complex is less than the distance to the nearest public and environmental receptor. 

WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO -FLAMMABLE
Tioga Gas Plant identified potential candidates for worst-case scenarios and utilized the services of the Baker Engineering and Risk Consultants, Inc. of San Antonio, Texas to perform consequence analyses using the commercially available DNV Technica PHAST professional version 5.01 dispersion program and the Baker-Strehlow-Tang (BST) methodology for determining the RMP designated 1-psi overpressure contour.

According to the analyses, the greatest maximum end point for a 1-psi vapor cloud explosion (VCE) is 820 feet from the center of the explosion, resulting from the instantaneous release of the inventory contained in the Butane Storage Bullet when filled to the greatest amount allowed (274,429 pounds). 

TOXICS
Based on the criteria in 40 CFR 68.10, the distance to the specified endpoint for the toxic worst-case accidental release scenario for the Tioga Gas Plant Complex Inlet Receiver reaches a public receptor. 

WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO - TOXICS
The Tioga Gas Plant Complex identified the Inlet Receiver within the High Pressure Inlet Receiver and Condensate Process as the candidate for the toxic Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S) worst case release scenario.  Analy

ses utilizing the commercially available DNV Technica PHAST version 6.53.1 dispersion program were performed to identify areas that were within the toxic endpoint of 0.042 mg/L. A public receptor was identified as being within the toxic endpoint for the worst case release scenario.  

According to analyses the worst case toxic endpoint of 0.042 mg/L distance is 2.5 miles from the center of a 10 minute release of inventory of 11,430 pounds of H2S contained within the Inlet Receiver.

The toxic release inventory used for the analysis was the maximum quantity of H2S that could be present within the Inlet Receiver based upon a projection of potential future inventory compositions and amounts resulting from well production forecasts.




ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS - FLAMMABLE AND TOXICS
Candidates for more likely alternative release scenarios were identified and assessed to determine the furthest offsite effect that could affect a public receptor. A limited number of public receptors were identified to be within the toxic endpoint for the alternative release scenario [no public or environmental receptors were identified within flammable endpoints, ie; (1 psi overpressure, 5 kw/m2 for 40 seconds and Lower Flammability Limit per NFPA].  The Tioga Gas Plant Complex is coordinating emergency response plans with the Williams Country Emergency Services and 9-1-1 Director.

OTHER
Within the past five years, Tioga Gas Plant Complex has had no accidental release that caused offsite impacts as defined by the Risk Management Program rule (40 CFR 68.10(b)(1). No additional measures beyond those stated in the Planned Changes to Improve Safety section of the executive summary are necessary to prevent offsite impacts from accidental releases. In the event of fire, explosion, or a release of a regulated substance from the process, entry within the distance to the specified endpoints may pose a danger to public emergency responders. Therefore, public emergency responders should not en

ter this area except as arranged with the emergency contact indicated in the RMP.


The undersigned certifies that, to the best of my knowledge, information, and belief formed after reasonable inquiry, the information submitted is true, accurate and complete.
Rory Nelson
________________________________ ________________________________
Signature
PLANT MANAGER
_______________________________________ _________________________________
Title Date


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES
The Tioga Gas Plant Complex has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the investment of significant resources in accident prevention, such as personnel training, mechanical inspection, process control systems and by recognition of safety as a primary factor in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our processes. However, if an accidental release does occur, trained plant personnel will respond to control and contain the release.
To prevent accidental releases, the Tioga Gas Plant Complex achieves control of hazardous materials by:

AÂ¿ A commitment to OSHA's Process Safety Management and HAZWOPER standards, EPA's RMP, and the 
    Department of Transportation's Hazardous Materials Transportation Act regulations, which promote 
    and require adherence to process safety activities designed to prevent accidental releases.
BÂ¿ Development and use of Hess Corporation and Tioga Gas Plant Complex safety, operating, 
    maintenance, emergency response, engineering design and construction policies, procedures and 
    practices designed to prevent accidents and potential releases.
CÂ¿ Knowledge of and adherence to applicable industry recognized and generally accepted good 
    engineering practices  (RAGAGEP), specifications and recommended practices that address and provide 
    guidance for the proper design, construction and operation of facilities containing hazardous materials.
D  A comprehensive equipment

inspection and testing program.





DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The Tioga Gas Plant Complex, located at 10340 68th Street NW, Williams County, North Dakota processes raw natural gas from area oil/gas wells to produce Propane, Butane, Natural Gasoline, Sulfur, and clean Natural Gas for industrial and residential use. The plant has several regulated flammables, such as Methane, Ethane, Propane, Butane, and Natural Gas Condensate.  The High Pressure Inlet Receiving and Condensate process could contain H2S above the threshold quantity.  It is this process only that is being submitted as a Level 3 process for both toxics and flammables.  In addition, other processes within the plant produce and contain as by-products, Hydrogen Sulfide and Sulfur Dioxide at levels below the listed RMP threshold quantities.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
Processes at the Tioga Gas Plant Complex that are regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation are also subject to the Occupational Safety & Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation 1910.119. The Tioga Gas Plant Complex adheres to all applicable federal and state regulatory statutes.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Within the past five years, the Tioga Gas Plant Complex has had no accidental release that caused offsite
impacts as defined by the Risk Management Program rule (40 CFR 68.10(b)(1). Within the past 5 years the
plant has not experienced an incident involving regulated flammables or toxics that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, public evacuations or sheltering in place.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION
The Tioga Gas Plant Complex maintains a written emergency response program, which is designed to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possib

ility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is involved. The procedure addresses emergency response, proper first aid and medical treatment, evacuation plans, accounting for personnel, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public. In addition, the plant has procedures that address maintenance, inspection and testing and instructions in the use of emergency response equipment. The emergency response program includes elements required to be within the facility response plan for the alternative release scenario. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to gas plant processes or other plant facilities.

WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO
The Tioga Gas Plant Complex identified potential candidates for worst case scenarios and utilized the services of the Baker Engineering and Risk Consultants, Inc. of San Antonio, Texas to perform consequence analyses using the commercially available DNV Technica PHAST professional version 5.01 dispersion program and the Baker- Strehlow-Tang (BST) methodology for determining the RMP designated 1 psi overpressure contour.

According to the analyses, the greatest maximum end point for a 1-psi vapor cloud explosion (VCE) is 820 feet from the center of the explosion, resulting from the instantaneous release of the inventory contained in the Butane storage bullet when filled to the greatest amount allowed (274,429 pounds). This worst-case release would not affect any public or environmental receptor beyond property owned and occupied by Tioga Gas Plant.

The Tioga Gas Plant Complex identified potential candidates for toxic (H2S) worst case release scenarios.
These potential candidates were analyzed using the commercially available DNV Technica PHAST version 6.53.1 dispersion program to identify areas that were within the toxic endpoint of 0.042 mg/L. Public receptor

s were identified as being within the toxic endpoint for the worst case release scenario.
Candidates for alternative more likely releases were identified and assessed to determine those most likely to have the furthest offsite affect that could affect a public receptor. A limited number of public receptors were within the toxic endpoint for the alternative release scenarios.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Tioga Gas Plant Complex conducts ongoing efforts to reduce risk through the Risk Management Program and Process Safety Management. These include recommendations from process hazards analyses, employee suggestions, incident investigations, compliance audits and a review of the preventative maintenance and mechanical integrity programs.
